results.headline: ‘Quinceañera’: Turning Sweet 15 in Los Angeles’s Immigrant Stew

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Quinceanera

results.summary_short: This portrait of a Mexican-American family in Los Angeles is as smart and warmhearted an exploration of an upwardly mobile immigrant culture as American independent cinema has produced.

results.headline: ‘The Descent’: Six Women, a Dark Cave and Some Very Scary Monsters

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Descent

results.summary_short: The babes are buff and the scares bountiful in Neil Marshall's full-throttle horror freakout about six women on a caving expedition.

results.headline: In Claude Chabrol’s Film ‘The Bridesmaid,’ a Mama’s Boy Meets a Femme Fatale

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Bridesmaid

results.summary_short: In his latest film, Mr. Chabrol again takes up a sharp instrument and directs it at one of his favorite targets, the family.

results.headline: ‘Talladega Nights’: The Men Are Rowdy, the Cars Are Fast and the Product Placement Is Extreme
results.display_title: Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby

results.summary_short: As a cultural artifact, “Talladega Nights” is both completely phony and, therefore, utterly authentic. Or, to put it differently: this movie is the real thing.

results.headline: A Gay Detective Goes Undercover in 'Shock to the System'

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Shock to the System

results.summary_short: This is a sly, refreshingly grown-up gay entertainment, though rather less satisfying as a thriller.

results.headline: ‘The Puffy Chair’ Tells the Story of a Trip to Atlanta (and to Adulthood)

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Puffy Chair

results.summary_short: “The Puffy Chair” is a low-key road movie that has knocked around the festival circuit for a while, and the journey it depicts is similarly unhurried.

results.headline: A Long-Distance Friendship, and Then It Gets Strange, in 'The Night Listener'

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Night Listener

results.summary_short: Based on a novel by Armistead Maupin, which was based in turn on an episode in Mr. Maupin’s life, “The Night Listener” explores a shadowy region between truth and fiction.

results.headline: 'Jailbait': As Time Goes By

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jailbait

results.summary_short: This stagy, only mildly compelling prison drama ends up feeling like purgatory to all involved.

results.headline: Iraq Under a Microscope in 'My Country, My Country'

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Country, My Country

results.summary_short: Laura Poitras's documentary is an appropriately mournful look at the chaos of Iraq under American occupation.

results.headline: ‘Boynton Beach Club’ Has Crazy Mixed-Up Teenagers in Their 60’s

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Boynton Beach Club

results.summary_short: You might be excused for speculating that this movie is really a high school romantic comedy whose teenage characters are played by their grandparents.

results.headline: Party Animals Take Over in 'Barnyard'

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Barnyard: The Original Party Animals

results.summary_short: Aimed at wee ones who like their colors bright and their stories elemental, this feature animation is, you could say, udderly strange.

results.headline: ‘Vacationland’ Depicts a Gay Man’s Path to College, With Lots of Excess

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Vacationland

results.summary_short: A generic coming-of-age movie whose arrival on the scene suggests that the audience for gay indie clunkers is inexhaustible.

results.headline: ‘Miami Vice’: Operatic Passions, Yet Cool in the Heat

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Miami Vice

results.summary_short: Mixing pop savvy with startling formal ambition, Michael Mann transforms a long, fairly predictable cop-show episode into a dazzling (and sometimes daft) Wagnerian spectacle.

results.headline: ‘Scoop’:  Shades of Nick and Nora, With Woody Allen’s Shtick

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Scoop

results.summary_short: In his not especially funny yet oddly appealing new comedy, Woody Allen manages to act his age and prove there’s life in those old jokes yet.

results.headline: In '13 Tzameti,' the Sadistic Blood Lust of an Attempt to Get Rich Quick

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 13 (Tzameti)

results.summary_short: This flashy black-and-white thriller suggests a French new-wave film infected with a virulent strain of Eastern European nihilism.

results.headline: 'By the People' Explores the Brute Facts of Election Day

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of By The People

results.summary_short: This affable, painfully idealistic documentary goes behind the scenes of an election to illustrate the endless bureaucratic minutia involved in letting people vote.

results.headline: 'John Tucker Must Die' Declares a Trio of Teenage Girlfriends

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of John Tucker Must Die

results.summary_short: A dispiriting teen comedy about a preening basketball star whose three girlfriends plot payback for the damage he has supposedly inflicted on their brittle little hearts.

results.headline: ‘I Like Killing Flies’: A Side of Salty Language for a Soup-to-Nuts Menu

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I Like Killing Flies

results.summary_short: Matt Mahurin's documentary offers a portrait of Kenny Shopsin, of the legendary or notorious, depending on your experience, Greenwich Village eatery that bears his name.

results.headline: ‘Brothers of the Head’: Inseparable Rock Princes, as Real as an Air Guitar

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Brothers of the Head

results.summary_short: A fake documentary that barely lets on that it's fiction, this devilishly clever film tells the story of conjoined twins who create a minor sensation in Britain on the eve of punk rock.

results.headline: ‘The Ant Bully,’ in Which the Bugs Sound Like Movie Stars

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Ant Bully

results.summary_short: "The Ant Bully," the latest computer-animated plea for interspecies understanding, provides a few moments of inventiveness and wit.
